subject: Re: [junit] Including test cases with production code
msgSnippet: ... Agreed.  If you don t include JUnit with your release, your test will _never_ run.  And if your customer is an end-user I doubt that he will install JUnit
messageBody:
>
>
>Can someone explain why someone (i.e. a customer) would want to clutter
>their storage or bandwith with test cases?
>
Agreed. If you don't include JUnit with your release, your test will
_never_ run. And if your customer is an end-user I doubt that he will
install JUnit and look into the jar to find the AllTest.java file :-)

You can be proud of your test code but I think that it's better said in
the release note: "JUnit -the leading testing framework for Java
application- has executed xxx tests to ensure that your application's
quality meets the highest standards... blah blah blah" :-)

-Vladimir
